title: Interpreting R-Squared Value in Gas Mileage and Speed Comparison
question_text:
The speed (in kilometers per hour) and mileage (in kilometers per liter) of $13\text{ cars}$ was measured. The regression equation is as follows:
$\text{Kilometers per liter} = -1.80 + 0.54\text{ kilometers per hour}$
$S = 7.15740$ $R^2= 64.8\%$ $R^2 \text{ (adj)} = 61.5\%$
What is a valid interpretation of $R^2$ in the context of the problem?

choices.text: About $65\%$ of the observations are within one standard deviation of the mean.
About $65\%$ of the observations will follow this linear model.
About $65\%$ of the data can be explained in this situation.
About $65\%$ of the variation in fuel economy (as measured by kilometers per liter) can be explained by the least squares regression line on speed (as measured by kilometers per hour).
About $65\%$ of the time, the true population slope will be caught within the given interval.

solution:
The definition of $R^2$ is the fraction of variation in $y$ that can be explained by the least squares regression line on $x$ where $y$ represents the response variable and $x$ represents the explanatory variable. One can see that $R^2$ is about $64.8\%$, which can be rounded to $65\%$.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. It is true that if data is approximately normal, then $68\%$ of observations will be within one standard deviation of the mean. However, this rule applies to single variable data and does not relate in any way to $R^2$.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. The value of $R^2$ does not give the percentage of data points that follow the model. Furthermore, the idea of a point following the model can be quite subjective.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. This selection gives a vague definition of R2, but does not provide context. Make sure all answers provide context!

Choice 'E' is incorrect. It is true that one could construct a linear regression T-interval to estimate the true unknown population slope. However, this interval does not directly relate to the value of R2.
